poem:
### Corrections and Clarifications

In headlines where numbers whirl like loose kites,  
the cost of sorrow is tallied,  
discrepancies smudged as inked ribbons.  
Babies and mothers become figures,  
€20 to cross a border of paper.  
But grief—a silent river—  
flows without raking, beyond  
the reach of calculators and prints.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • We said the NHS had “paid out £134m in the nine years to March 2023 to the families of nearly 300 women and about 400 babies who died in NHS settings”. That figure includes legal costs; the damages paid to families amounted to £76m (The £27bn bill for failings in mother and baby care, 21 July, p6 from p1). • The Etias visa waiver will cost €20 when it is introduced". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
